titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Employed in domestic concerns most of the morning— After dinner I went to my father’s. Transplanted to the nursery there several peach-trees from the stones I planted last September— But I apprehend it is almost too late in the Season for transplanting trees this year from the Stone— At least I find that those I transplanted earliest, both last Spring and the preceding one, have succeeded much the best.— Of the last Summer’s budding, I find that the peaches &c inoculated on plum-stocks, and the cherries on wild cherry Stocks have all failed— But Apples, Peaches and one pear inoculated on their respective Stocks have succeeded very well.— Read Martyn’s 19th: Letter— And the french abregé de Rhetorique.

2 I went to my father’s this morning, and resumed the perusal of Aristotle’s Rhetorics, which I began last Summer, but did not go through— Wrote also a little— Dined there— Mrs: W. Smith and her daughter Eliza were there— At 4 in the afternoon I went to Neponsit Bridge, to attend the meeting of the Directors. We could not make a Quorum, Mr: Quincy and Mr: T. Greenleaf being the only members who attended. Mr: Foster, and Mr: Shaw were there— We stayed untill past 6. and then adjourned to meet at Mr: Quincy’s, next Tuesday at 4 P.M.— Returned home just at dusk.— I read a letter of Martyn on Botany.

3. At the brook. Found some new flowers— Two hours in the forenoon at my fathers— Home to dinner— Expected Mr: and Mrs: H. Otis, with T. Johnson in the afternoon, from Boston, but they did not come— Went with the Ladies botanizing just before dark in the Evening— Heat and Drought very great— I read a Chapter of Aristotle, and wrote a little in the morning— Read Captain Woodward’s Narrative, and a letter of Martyn in the afternoon.

4. Independence Day. Bathed at Mr: Black’s wharf— Spent the day at my father’s— The heat somewhat affected my studies— Pass’d most of the forenoon under the Cherry-trees shooting Robins and other small birds, & one pigeon. Mrs: Adams and Eliza came in the afternoon, we return’d home together— I began to learn by heart Les Racines Grecques— Wrote— And finished reading the French Abrègé de Rhetorique.
John—2. f. 7. i.— George 3 f. 3 1/2 i.

5. Bathed at Bracket’s landing early this morning.— The creek has very much filled up since the time when I was wont to bathe there, as a Child— Mrs: Adams and Eliza went over to Milton this forenoon. I expected Mr: Quincy to have called on me to go to Boston; but he did not come— We again expected Mr: & Mrs: Otis, but they did not make their appearance. I gathered some flowers in the morning alone; and in the Evening with the Ladies. Mrs: Adams in the Evening was unwell— I finished reading Woodard’s Narrative; read also a couple of Martyn’s letters, and some pages of Burns the Scottish Poet.

6. My brother called here this morning— I went with him to my father’s at about 12. o’clock. We dined at Mr: Black’s, with the Club. Dr: Holbrook, and two Gentlemen from Boston, Mr: Lamb’s, were of the Company. I left them early in the afternoon, but came home somewhat late.— Read nothing.

7. Heard a Mr: Mellen— A preacher of the days that are past. In the afternoon I went to my father’s; and my family were all there— Return’d home late in the Evening— This day completes four weeks without rain— The Season suffers severely by the drought— I resumed the Racines Grecques. and read Tillotson’s Sermons 79 and 80.

8. Morning at home— Read a couple of Martyn’s letters— Afternoon at my father’s, with Aristotle— Les Racines Grecques, and writing. I returned home early in the evening— We had one of the most violent thunder storms, I ever witness’d— It Struck a fence between me and Dr: Phipps; not forty rods distant from my house— It was however short, and the sky soon cleared away again.

9. I went this morning to my father’s and dined there; at 4 this afternoon I went to Mr Quincy’s and attended the adjourned meeting of the Directors of Neponsit Bridge— Mr: Greenleaf & Mr: Beale overtook me, and took me with them in the chaise. Mr: Rogers & his family were at Mr: Quincy’s— On my return Mr: Quincy walk’d with me to my father’s— Came home with Mrs: Cranch— Read Aristotle & Les Racines Grecques.

10. At my father’s this forenoon— A Chapter of Aristotle, and writing— Dr: Tufts & his Lady, with Miss Jenks, Mr Quincy and his family, Miss H. Adams, and my mother were here at tea this afternoon. In the evening Mr: Townsend, and Mr: D. Greenleaf called, and spent an hour with us— I read the last two letters of Martyn’s Botany.

11. Mr: Townsend called on me this morning, and I went with him to my father’s— My brother was there, and after spending an hour with him we return’d together— They had company there to dinner, Miss Breck & Miss Wilson—Mr: Hall, & Mr: Sumner—Mr: Whitwell and Mr: Shaw— I went there again in the afternoon; the ladies also— We came home early in the Evening— Read little or Nothing— I enter this day upon my thirty-ninth year—

12 The extremity of the weather kept me confined the greatest part of the day to my own house: which is a painful interruption of my studies. I wrote a little— Continued my application to the Racine’s Grecques— Read part of the first Volume of Hayley’s life of Cowper— In the afternoon I stroll’d o’er the grounds behind my house— In the Evening the two Mr: Greenleaf’s and their Ladies paid us a visit; and Mr: & Mrs: H. G. Otis, with their two daughters, one still shorter.

13. The extremity of the heat again kept me at home all the morning. But we dined with the club at my father’s— Mrs: Adams not being very well did not go— Read further in the first volume of Cowper’s life, and continued the Racines Grecques— My proper application continues still interrupted, by the overpowering heat.

14. Mrs: Adams very unwell— Bled by Dr: Phipps— I heard Mr: Fiske of Cambridge— My Mother was here in the Evening. Our boy Newell went home sick— Read Tillotson’s Sermons 81. and 82. On worshipping dead, and persecuting living Saints— And on Zeal without knowledge— His attacks on the Catholic Religion are incessant, and at this day would appear illiberal— Read also in Hayley’s Life of Cowper.— The book principally consists of Cowper’s Correspondence.

15. After a day of intermission the heat again returned with great excess.— My thermometer has never risen higher than 87.—but those of other Gentlemen have been at 95 and 97.— Mine is in the coolest room of the house; and most distant from the Sun— My brother called here this afternoon— I was going with him to my fathers, but was detained by Mr: T. B. Johnson, who came out from Boston with Mr: Gordon— They returned this Evening— Mr: & Mrs: Apthorp also called upon us— Mrs: Adams continues unwell.

16. My Mother called this morning— And I went down with her— Spent the day in the Office at my father’s, reading and writing.— All the family but himself went in the afternoon to Mr: Quincy’s— Miss H. Adams went there to dinner— I walk’d home this Evening— Heat continues excessive— Read a little of Aristotle and Quinctilian, and wrote also a little

17. At the Brook this morning with George— Mrs: Adams again quite unwell. Heat of the weather still so great that I could not leave home— In the Evening we had the outer skirt of a thunder-cloud, and a bare sprinkling of rain— Wrote a little— Racines Grecques— Read, Life of Cowper, and Blair’s Lectures.

18. Heat not so extreme as for some days past, but still violent. I have not known for many years, if ever, so long a succession of great heat in this climate. Towards Evening I went to my father’s, spent an hour there and then return’d— Mrs: Adams yet unwell— Read Cowper’s posthumous Poems— Blair’s Lectures, and wrote— Racines Grecques.—these give me a steady occupation about two hours each day. I learn by heart three Stanza’s, exactly like a School boy— I shall see whether to any use—for I find that my memory never retains the yesterday’s lesson.

19. I spent the morning, and part of the afternoon, in the regular occupations I have lately assumed.— Wrote—and read Blair’s Lectures— We all went to tea at my father’s, where we found a Company of Ladies. Mrs: Adams was very unwell again in the Evening.

20. Eliza Johnson, went to Boston this morning with my brother; intending to spend some days there. Dined with the Club at Boston— Mr: D. Greenleafy br Mr: D. Greenleaf’s— My brother return’d from Boston and was there— At a tea-party this Evening at Mr: Millar’s; with a company of Ladies.

21. The meeting house is undergoing repairs and a process of enlargement; which prevent any performance of public worship there this day— I heard Mr: Blackburn at Church— My Aunt Smith dined with us— In the afternoon I went to my father’s; and with him paid a visit at Mr: Quincy’s; we found nobody at home— My father came home with me— I read the 83d: and 84th: Sermons of Tillotson; and the preface to the Abbé Gedoyn’s french translation of Quinctilian— Explanation at home.

22. Somewhat unwell the former part of the day— Afternoon went with Mrs: Adams to Mr: Quincy’s; Miss Wilson was there; and Mr: Shaw. We came home early in the Evening.— Read the first Book of Quinctilian, in the Abbé Gedoyn’s french translation— It contains many valuable observations, but consists chiefly of grammatical criticisms, on the use of certain words— Made some extracts from Juvenal.

23. Mrs: Adams went to Boston this morning with Mr: D. Greenleaf; but finding herself much fatigued, did not return at Night— She sent me word by Mr: Greenleaf to come for her to-morrow— Took my youngest child with me to my father’s, where we dined— Miss S. Storer was there. My brother brought me to Mr: Cranch’s on the way home— I walk’d the remainder of the way— I continue my exercises in learning the Racines Grecques— 3. Stanza’s a day. It seems to me that in continuing the practice, I acquire some facility; and I can now dispatch my task in an hour, which sometimes at first took me nearly double that time— But I still invariably forget every lesson, but that of the day— As a school-boy I should pass muster— But as to the use of my learning it is very doubtful— Read the Second Book of Quintilian— And miscellaneously this afternoon, at my father’s— La Harpe— A Chapter of Aristotle— The preface to the Port-Royal Greek Grammar— Gibbon’s Memoirs &c— In the Evening at home two Chapters of the Greek Testament—

24. I went into Boston this morning for Mrs: Adams, and brought her home this Evening. Dined at Whitcomb’s. Before I left my father’s, he gave me a letter, received last Evening from R. Bird, enclosing Mr: Swan’s note, endorsed by Genl. Jackson— I called twice on this Gentleman to demand payment of the note; which he refused— He urged me not to sue it, and begg’d for time— Untill Mr: Swan should arrive—or untill he could consult a lawyer, to know how soon he would be compell’d by law to pay the money. This was obviously trifling with me— I sued the note, to the next Circuit Court. I drew on Mr: Williams, for £450, and purchased 20 Shares in the New-England, Marine Insurance Company.— Could of course read nothing this day.

25. Spent the whole day at home, excepting a solitary walk, which I took towards Evening— Read the third Book of Quinctilian— Gedoyn’s Translation— Blairs Lectures 10–13.— Juvenal Sat: 3. in part, & made Extracts. 2. Chapters in the Greek Testament— I write nothing yet.

26. Day at home industriously employed—towards Evening went to my father’s— Found the ladies were gone to my uncle’s to tea, and went to them. Thunder shower came up— I walk’d home in the midst of it— Very little rain— The drought is greater, than I have ever known— I read Quintilian Book 4 and began Book 5— Blair’s Lectures 14–17. Greek Testament, 2 Chapters— Juvenal Sat: 4. and Racines Grecques— My Mother informed me that the Overseers of the University had yesterday confirmed the choice of the Corporations for the professorship of Oratory.

27. We dined at my father’s in company with the Trustees of the Agricultural Society. Home early this Evening— Read the remainder of Quinctilian Book 5.— Greek Testament 2 Chapters— Extract from part of Juvenal Sat: 5. and in the Evening, Flechier Oraison funebre, on the Duchess of Montausier—

28. The Meeting-House still under repairs, and no service there. Heard Mr: Gardner at Church— In the Evening Mr: Charles Harrod called upon us with his sister, Mrs: T. B. Adams— Mrs: Smith also was here. I read the 85th: Sermon of Tillotson, which closes the 4th: volume, and now find myself as I have been several times before, obliged to suspend further reading him in course, not having the subsequent volume at hand— Read also Fléchier’s Oraison funébre on the duchess d’Aiguillon; and the preface to this volume of his works.

29. This afternoon I went to tea at Mr: Black’s— Mrs: Adams was not well enough to go out. There was the usual company of ladies and Gentlemen— I came home later than usual in the Evening— Read Quinctilian Book 6.—and Blair’s Lectures 18–22.

30. Eliza Johnson return’d this afternoon from Boston— Her brother came with her and went back this Evening.— Tea at Mr: Apthorp’s; but Mrs: Adams did not go— I called afterwards at Mr: Cranch’s, but found no letters there— Read Quinctilian Book 7. and Blair’s Lectures 23–26. Juvenal Sat: 5. and begun Sat: 6.

31. I received this morning from Mr: Shaw, the rules and Statutes respecting the Professorship of Rhetoric, and notice that a Committee of the Corporation and Overseers, would come out to-morrow morning— This afternoon, we went down to my father’s, and pass’d the Evening there. Mr: & Mrs: T. Greenleaf and Miss Saltonstall were there— Read Quinctilian Book 8— Blair’s Lectures 27–29.—and Juvenal Sat: 6.

Day— Rise usually about 6— Employed one hour in learning by heart Three Stanza’s of the Racines Grecques. And another in reading two Chapters of the Greek Testament— I have thus gone through 71. of the first, and 16. Chapters of Matthew in the last— Breakfast— Journalize— Extract from Juvenal, and read a Book of Quinctilian in the french Translation— This with occasional family avocations brings me to the hour of dinner, between 1 and 2.— Dine— Rest an hour and sometimes two— Read three or four of Blair’s lectures; then walk or ride to my father’s, or into company for the Evening untill 9.— Then sup, and between 10 and 11 retire for the Night— I have thus resumed a course of very assiduous, and to me very pleasing occupation. I never have had one more agreeable to me— But the prospect of labour before me is so boundless, and that of utility to be derived from it so obscure that I am almost appall’d and discouraged— Yet with the blessing of Heaven, and especially, if my health can be indulged me, I will not despair— For health of body and perseverance of mind, I must implore the being from whom alone every good and perfect gift descends.
